20020602 (F2)

I don't think I can repeat this, but I will try.
For now, here's what I did, and here's the stack trace(s) from the log.
- Did a Java Search in an SWT working set for a field called SWT.ON_TOP.
- Looked at a few results (which opened a few editors)
- Closed the editors
- Decided to do a File Search for the string ON_TOP in the same working set (to 
do this, I simply clicked on search again and clicked on the File Search tab - 
the search field was already filled in for me).
- I got the following walkbacks in my .log:

I seem to be able to replicate this.
It doesn't matter what the working set is, but for some reason, search doesn't 
like to look for my string ON_TOP (case sensitive checked). The search 
completes (at least, I think it does) but the search dialog does not close.
The walkbacks are added to the .log. Unfortunately, I am now in a state where I 
cannot look at any of the search results without getting the same walkback. I 
will restart eclipse and try again.

Replicated in a brand-new launch of eclipse.
Here are the exact steps to repeat, if it helps.
- create a workspace for developing SWT (if detailed steps needed here, please 
email me. Note that you need to set the .classpath to the .classpath_xxx for 
the platform you are running on).
- open an editor on the file SWT.java
- select the field ON_TOP
- click the search tool
- do a Java search (in a working set containing only the org.eclipse.swt 
project)
- after the search completes, you will have one search result - double-click 
the result to open an editor on Shell
- close the editor on Shell
- give focus to the editor on SWT again
- click the search tool again
- now click on the File Search tab
- click Search
Walkback in .log.

I will paste the new walkback here because it is a tiny bit different than 
before. There is one extra stack frame, and for some reason, all of the stack 
frames have line numbers, which could be useful for debugging this problem.
